journal-meta.journal-title: World Journal for Pediatric and Congenital Heart Surgery

title-group.article-title: Serum Cardiac Troponin T in Asphyxiated Term Neonates Delivered at Two Teaching Hospitals in Lagos, Nigeria

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Paediatrics, Lagos University Teaching Hospital, Idi-Araba, Lagos, Nigeria
2Department of Paediatrics, Lagos State University Teaching Hospital, Ikeja, Lagos, Nigeria

author-notes.corresp: Chinyere C. Uzodimma, Department of Paediatrics, Lagos University Teaching Hospital, Idi-Araba, Lagos, Nigeria Email: cuzodimma@yahoo.com

permissions.copyright-holder: World Society for Pediatric and Congential Heart Surgery

abstract.p: Background: Asphyxia is a leading cause of perinatal morbidity and mortality in the developing countries. All organs including the myocardium are vulnerable to ischemic injury in asphyxia. The aim of the current study was to assess myocardial injury in asphyxiated full-term neonates using their serum cardiac troponin T levels. Methods: In all, 30 term asphyxiated neonates and 30 gestational age-, birth weight-, and sex-matched controls were studied. Asphyxia was defined by double criteria of low umbilical arterial blood pH <7.20 and low five-minutes Apgar score ≤6, while the controls were term nonasphyxiated neonates with umbilical arterial blood pH ≥7.20 and five minutes Apgar score >6. The umbilical arterial pH was done soon after delivery, while the serum cardiac troponin T was done within the first 4 to 24 hours of life. Results: Participants and controls were similar in terms of mean gestational age, mode of delivery, gender, and birth weight (P = 1.0, .07, 1.0, and 1.0, respectively). Two thirds of the asphyxiated babies had elevated serum cardiac troponin T in the high risk range (> 0.1 ng/mL). On the contrary, none of the controls had serum cardiac troponin T in that range. Serum cardiac troponin T showed negative correlation with pH (r = −.75), five-minute Apgar score (r = −.74), and one-minute Apgar score (r = −0.70). Conclusion: The study identified perinatal asphyxia as a high-risk factor for elevated serum cardiac troponin T and hence for myocardial cellular injury.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Worldwide, in the year 2000, complications of asphyxia together with preterm birth and severe infection accounted for 86% of the neonatal deaths and more than three quarters of these deaths occurred in the first week after birth. 1 Likewise, in Nigeria, perinatal asphyxia is one of the leading causes of neonatal deaths. Studies in Nigeria have found an incidence of asphyxia between 100 and 180 per thousand live births and accounting for 16% to 55% of neonatal deaths. 2
–7

“Perinatal asphyxia” refers to hypoxic or ischemic insult to the fetus or new born that is of sufficient magnitude and duration to cause more than fleeting biochemical or functional changes. 8 Apgar score has been shown to correlate with asphyxia. It is a scoring method described by Virginia Apgar which assesses the condition (respiration, heart rate, color, tone, and reflex activity) of the newborn at birth. 9 A well baby would have a score of 7 and above and the asphyxiated neonate will often have low Apgar score of 6 and below. 9 –11 Acidosis is always present in perinatal asphyxia and can be reliably assessed by the blood pH. Previous studies have defined asphyxia with cutoff values of umbilical arterial blood pH <7.2. 10

Myocardial ischemia and its effect on cardiac function can be assessed by electrocardiography (ECG), echocardiography, assay of biochemical markers, and autopsy. 8 Biochemical markers of myocardial injury include creatine kinase (CK-MB) and the cardiac troponins. Cardiac troponin T (cTnT) as a biochemical marker is an emerging aspect of diagnosis and has revolutionized the definition of adult myocardial infarction. 12 Troponin is an inhibitory protein complex located on the actin filament of the cardiac muscle and is elaborated in cardiac muscle death such as that may occur in hypoxic–ischemic injury. 13 The advantages of cTnT over the previous markers like creatine kinase include its cardiac specificity and attribute of being unaffected by trauma, mode of delivery, birth weight, and sex. 14 The cTnT exists as both cytoplasmic and structural protein. The cytoplasmic pool is the source of cTnT released into the circulation within 4 to 6 hours and peaks at 24 to 36 hours after injury. The structural protein is responsible for the second blunted peak that occurs 2 to 4 days after injury. 13

The relationship between perinatal asphyxia and hypoxic myocardial injury has been studied in various contexts. Previous studies have dealt with the ECG and echocardiographic changes prior to the discovery of the highly sensitive troponin assay. The ECG and echocardiography have their own limitations. The ECG of normal newborns is prone to normal physiologic changes in the first few days of life, 15 and this together with the small chest wall of newborns make the ECG a variable tool for assessing perinatal asphyxia-related myocardial infarction. Also, the study by Omokhodion et al 16 highlighted that there may be racial differences in ECG responses. On the other hand, the echocardiographic assessment may detect functional changes but does not necessarily indicate its relation to myocardial cellular death.

The strength of the highly sensitive troponin T is that it is useful in detecting myocardial cellular injury. Although the serum cTnT is routinely assayed for the evaluation of adult myocardial infarction, its usefulness in perinatal asphyxia-related myocardial infarction has been under intense investigation in recent years. The current study may be one of the pioneer efforts at bridging the gap of knowledge in perinatal asphyxia-related myocardial injury among term African newborns. It is hoped that the findings in this study will add to the available data and contribute to the growing body of knowledge on perinatal asphyxia. The selection of participants by both Apgar score and umbilical arterial blood pH provided the opportunity to do a multivariable analysis, thus placing these indices in their rightful places in the context of asphyxia and its related myocardial ischemia.

It is conceivable that prompt detection of cardiovascular injury will impact on the overall management of asphyxiated neonates, reduce perinatal morbidity and mortality, and ultimately contribute to the achievement of the United Nations Millennium Development Goal 4 which focuses on reduction of childhood mortality. 17

sec.title: Participants and Methods
sec.p: Cases and controls were recruited from the delivery rooms and neonatal intensive care units (NICUs) of the Lagos University Teaching Hospital (LUTH) and the Lagos State University Hospital, Lagos (LASUTH). Full-term asphyxiated neonates with gestational age ≥37 weeks were consecutively recruited. Asphyxia was defined based on double criteria of five-minute Apgar score ≤6 and umbilical arterial blood pH <7.2. For ease of analysis, cases were divided into groups I to III, representing pH <7.10, 7.1 to 7.19, and ≥7.2, respectively. The controls were normal nonasphyxiated term neonates matched for age, birth weight, and sex. Echocardiogram was done to exclude congenital heart disease in all cases and controls. Written and verbal consent was obtained from at least one parent. Approval was obtained from the research and ethics committee of both institutions.

sec.title: Patient Handling Procedure
sec.p: Following delivery of a term new born, the Apgar scores were assigned routinely at one and five minutes of age by the attending midwife. If the Apgar score of a newly delivered neonate met the recruitment criteria, consent was then taken from a parent.

One milliliter of umbilical arterial blood was obtained through an umbilical catheter. The sample was collected as soon as possible after birth (within one hour). All samples for pH were collected anaerobically in heparinized vacuum tubes and analyzed immediately in the side laboratory. The approximate time to get pH results was about 15 minutes. If the pH criterion was met, the baby was definitely recruited into the study and then 1 mL of venous blood from a peripheral vein was collected for the serum cardiac troponin T assay within the first 4 to 24 hours of life. The age of the baby (hours) at the time of troponin test was recorded as “age at troponin test.” A predesigned proforma was used to record both clinical and laboratory data for all eligible newborns.

sec.title: pH
sec.p: pH was tested using ion selective electrode electrolyte analyzer 6000.

sec.title: Cardiac Troponin T test
sec.p: The bedside kit, Cobas h232 system manufactured by ROCHE, was used.

sec.title: Display and Interpretation of Results
sec.p: The total time required for displaying the test result is 14 minutes. The result of cTnT analysis is stratified and displayed by the Cobas h232 system as low risk (<0.03 ng/mL), medium risk (0.03-0.1 ng/ml), and high risk (>0.1 ng/mL). For the high-risk results (>0.1 ng/mL), absolute values were displayed on the equipment, while for low- and medium-risk values, results were displayed as ranges of “<0.03 ng/mL” or “0.03 to 0.1 ng/mL,” respectively. A high-risk result is synonymous with a positive test, indicative of myocardial cell damage.

sec.title: Quality Control Measures
sec.p: The Roche cardiac troponin T quality control was used according to manufacturer’s regulations.

sec.title: Echocardiography
sec.p: ALOKA Prosound 4000 ultrasound diagnostic equipment was used with the multifrequency pediatric phased array transducer (frequency range of 3.0-7.5 MHz).

sec.title: Data Analysis
sec.p: Data were analyzed using EPI info 2008 version 3.5.1. Chi-square test (Pearson) and odds ratios (ORs) with 95% confidence limits were used to test for statistical significance with respect to discrete data, while student t test was used for continuous data. Simple bivariate logistic regression model was setup with high-risk cTnT as the dependent variable and Apgar scores at one and five minutes, umbilical arterial blood pH, age of baby at troponin test, birth weight, and sex as independent variables. Next, multiple logistic regression models were setup with Apgar score at one and five minutes and the umbilical arterial blood pH as the independent variables. A probability value of less than .05 was considered statistically significant.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: A total of 32 babies were sampled for inclusion as asphyxiated participants, but two were excluded because their pH values were normal despite the low Apgar scores of ≤6 at five minutes. Thus, 30 babies who met the study criteria were recruited. Also, 30 of the 36 babies sampled for inclusion as controls were recruited because 6 of them had low pH values (<7.20) despite having good Apgar scores (≥7) at five minutes. Forty-two (70%) of the study population was recruited from LUTH, while the remaining 18 (30%) was recruited from LASUTH. Echocardiography was used to exclude congenital heart disease in all the cases.

sec.title: General Description of Study Population
sec.p: Participants and controls were similar in distribution of gender, mode of delivery, and birth weight (Table 1). The mean gestational age of primary participants was similar to that of controls (39.0 ± 1.5 vs 38.4 ± 1.2, t = 1.65, P = .1). The mean birth weight was 3168 ± 628.5 g and 3143 ± 574.1 g, respectively, for participants and controls (P = .87).

caption.p: Selected General Characteristics of Participants and Controlsa

fn.p: a Values in parentheses are percentages of n.

sec.title: The Apgar Score
sec.p: The Apgar score distribution is shown in Table 2.

caption.p: Apgar Score Distribution of the Babiesa

fn.p: a Values in parentheses are percentages of n.

sec.title: pH
sec.p: Table 3 shows the distribution of the pH groups. The mean level of pH for the participants and controls were 7.11 ± 0.08 and 7.26 ± 0.04, respectively.

caption.p: Relationship Between cTnT and pH Groups in Study Populationa

fn.p: a Figures in parentheses percentages of row total.

sec.title: Serum cTnT
sec.p: Asphyxiated participants were significantly more likely to have high-risk test results than controls (P = .00; Table 4). The mean value of serum cTnT among the participants with “high-risk” serum cTnT result was 0.3180 ± 0.2167 ng/mL (median = 0.27; range = 0.11-1.00 ng/mL).

caption.p: Distribution of Serum cTnT Test Resultsa,b

fn.p: b Values in parentheses are percentages of column total.

sec.title: Relationship Between Serum cTnT and Other Variables
Serum cTnT and umbilical arterial blood pH
sec.p: There was an inverse relationship between the pH and serum cTnT (Table 3 and Figure 1). Thus, babies who had normal pH were more likely to have low-risk levels of cTnT than their counterparts with abnormal pH (OR = 42.25, 95% confidence interval [CI] = 8-266.5, P < .05). Also group I patients (Table 3) with the worst pH values had almost thrice the mean value of cTnT as the group II (0.46 ± 0.22 ng/mL vs 0.17 ± 0.55; χ 2 = 12.98, degrees of freedom = 1, P = .0003). Figure 1 shows the inverse relationship between pH and cTnT levels in the 20 participants who had high-risk troponin levels.

caption.p: Relationship between serum cTnT and umbilical arterial blood pH.

sec.title: Serum cTnT and Apgar Score at One Minute
sec.p: Tables 5 and 6 show the relationship between Apgar score at one minute and cTnT. Taken together, babies who had first minute Apgar scores of ≤3 were 28 times as likely to have high-risk levels of cTnT than their counterparts with better Apgar scores (OR = 28.0, CI = 5.58-162.53). Furthermore, a simple linear correlation performed between Apgar score at first minute and cTnT showed a high correlation coefficient (r = −.70).

caption.p: Relationship Between Serum cTnT and Apgar Score Category of Participants

fn.p: a Values in parentheses are percentages of row total.

caption.p: Relationship Between Serum cTnT and Apgar Score Category for Controls

fn.p: a Values in parentheses are percentages of row total.

sec.title: Serum cTnT and Apgar Score at Five Minutes
sec.p: Two thirds of the primary participants who had persistently low fifth-minute Apgar scores had abnormally high-cTnT levels (Tables 5 and 6). In contrast, all 30 controls had five-minute Apgar scores of ≥7, with 26 (86.7%) of them having low-risk cTnT levels and none having high-risk levels. Further analysis showed a strong negative correlation between five-minute Apgar scores and cTnT levels (r = −.74).

sec.title: Relationship Between High-Risk cTnT and Selected Potential Determinants
sec.p: Six separate simple bivariate logistic regression models were setup with high-risk cTnT level as the dependent variable and Apgar scores at one minute, Apgar scores at five minutes, pH, age of baby at troponin test, birth weight, and sex as independent variables. The results are shown in Table 7. Apgar scores at one and five minutes as well as pH significantly correlated with high-risk troponin levels. No significant association was found between high-risk serum troponin T and age of baby at troponin test, sex, and birth weight. (odds ratios = 1.03, 2.33, and 1.00; 95% CI = 0.93-1.44, 0.75-7.29, and 0.99-1.00, respectively). Next, the 3 factors that were significantly associated with high-risk cTnT were introduced into a multiple logistic regression model (Table 8). Serum pH remained significantly associated with high-risk cTnT level, while Apgar scores both at one minute and at five minutes were no longer significantly associated (P = .003, .53, and .08, respectively).

caption.p: Simple Logistic Regression of High-Risk Serum cTnT Level on Selected Variables

fn.p: Abbreviations: CI, confidence interval; B, beta coefficient; SE, standard error.

caption.p: Multiple Logistic Regression of Serum cTnT Level on Other Variables

fn.p: Abbreviations: CI, confidence interval; cTnT, cardiac troponin T; SE, standard error.

sec.title: Serum cTnT and Mortality
sec.p: Of the 30 patients, 10 asphyxiated babies died, giving a mortality rate of 33.3%. Of these deaths, 9 (90%) had elevated serum troponin T. Therefore, death was the outcome in 9 (45%) of the 20 participants with high-risk cTnT levels, while 1 (10%) of the asphyxiated babies with medium-risk cTnT levels died. Asphyxiated neonates with elevated cTnT were about 7 times more likely to die than those without it (OR = 7.36; 95% CI = 0.68-186.10). No death was recorded among the controls. The mean age at death was 2.1 days ± 0.91 (range: 19 hours to 3 days, mode = 2 days).

sec.title: Comment
sec.p: Serum cTnT is a biochemical marker of myocardial cell death. Overall, we found that perinatal asphyxia in term neonates is associated with elevated serum cTnT level and hence myocardial cell death. Second, we noted that only the umbilical arterial blood pH, not Apgar scoring remained significantly associated with cTnT in a multivariable analysis.

The serum cardiac troponin T level among healthy neonates described in the current study falls below 0.1 ng/mL that has been reported in literature. 18 –20 Even though the current study did not describe the exact mean cTnT among the healthy neonates, the finding that nearly 90% of them had serum cTnT levels below the low-risk range of 0.03 ng/mL closely resembles the report of 0.003 ± 0.018 ng/mL by Rajakumar et al.

The demonstration of elevated serum cTnT levels in asphyxiated term neonates compared with their healthy counterparts in the current study is in conformity with previous studies. 18 –20 Perinatal asphyxia causes danger of hypoxic–ischemic injury to virtually every organ including the myocardium The heart which is initially preferentially perfused by the mechanism of the dive reflex soon becomes compromised as asphyxia progresses, leading to myocardial cellular death. Cardiac troponin T which is usually a cytoplasmic/structural protein is thus released into the blood causing it to be elevated above normal levels. 13

While there are clearly defined levels of cTnT for the diagnosis of adult myocardial infarction, that of postasphyxia myocardial ischemia has been under intense research in the past decade. 21 In the current study, asphyxiated neonates had elevated levels of cTnT in the high-risk range, while normal healthy neonates had low levels of serum cTnT, with majority falling below the conventional low-risk range of 0.03 ng/mL. The mean level of cTnT for asphyxiated neonates in the current study (0.32 ± 0.22 ng/mL) fell within the range of 0.141 to 0.34 ng/mL reported in the literature. 18 –20,22 Specifically, it is comparable to the mean reported by Gunes et al 18 (0.34 ± 0.21 ng/mL) but higher than 0.141 ± 0.226 ng/mL reported by Marta et al. 22 Similar to the mean cTnT level, the median (interquartile range) of 0.27 ng/mL (0.17-0.37) in the current study is slightly higher than 0.20 ng/mL (0.11-0.28) earlier reported by Costa et al. 19 The reason for differences in specific serum levels of cTnT may be traced to the diversity in criteria used for the definition of birth asphyxia. Earlier studies 18 –20,22 relied on different combinations of factors like low Apgar scores at one and/or five minutes, low umbilical artery pH, presence of meconium-stained amniotic fluid, respiratory distress as well as the Sarnat and Sarnat 23 staging for hypoxic–ischemic encephalopathy. Specifically, Costa et al defined asphyxia on the basis of Apgar scores alone as opposed to the current study in which umbilical artery pH was the key criterion. The problem of false positives attendant upon using Apgar scores alone may have been a confounding factor leading to lowering of serum cTnT levels reported by Costa et al.

Another methodological difference between the current study and that of Costa et al could be the gestational age of the study participants. While the current study was restricted to term neonates, the study by Costa et al included preterm babies. It is known that preterm babies may have low Apgar scores due to their peculiar features and not necessarily due to asphyxia. Therefore, inclusion of preterm babies may have led to false positives in the diagnosis of asphyxia. This may have translated to lower cTnT levels reported by Costa et al.

The more severe the asphyxia is, the higher the risk of myocardial damage. Hence, among asphyxiated participants, those with severely depressed pH (<7.10) had a higher mean level of serum cTnT than their counterparts with milder severity of asphyxia (pH >7.10).

The strong correlation between five minutes Apgar scores and serum troponin levels can be explained by persistent asphyxia which is encompassed in the low five-minute Apgar score. The combination of low Apgar scores and low pH in selecting participants for the current study provided an opportunity for interpretation of the significance of one-minute Apgar scores and improvement or otherwise at five minutes. The finding that participants with one-minute Apgar scores of ≤3 were far more likely to have elevated serum troponin levels than those who had scores of 4 to 6 has dire connotations. It indicates that while the five-minute score is more indicative of asphyxia and predictive of myocardial injury, the one-minute Apgar score may connote earlier onset of myocardial injury or faster progression of the myocardial injury in asphyxiated babies.

Furthermore, infants with moderately depressed scores at one minute who improved to normal scores at five minutes invariably appeared not to have suffered significant myocardial insult in that they had serum troponin levels below the high-risk range. In this respect, they fared better than their counterparts whose scores remained in the moderately depressed range even after five minutes. Nearly half of these latter participants had serum cardiac troponin T levels within the high-risk range. The findings provide evidence that duration of asphyxia has a dominant influence on the development of myocardial injury. Thus, emphasis should be placed on the need for strengthened efforts in effective neonatal resuscitation as a prerequisite for reducing postasphyxia morbidity and mortality.

In the current study, the exact timing of the troponin test within 4 to 24 hours of life (ie, age of the babies at troponin test), gender, and birth weight did not exert significant influence on serum cTnT level. This is in agreement with the earlier report by Clarke and Daniele. 14,24 The implication is that results could be uniformly interpreted without recourse to nomograms.

Even though we do not categorically attribute deaths to asphyxia alone, the mortality rate of 45% among neonates with elevated cTnT in our study is quite high. Significant myocardial injury would have compromised cardiac function and circulation, predisposing to mortality. This highlights the need for improved therapeutic interventions in the care of asphyxiated babies.

We recommend that while consistent efforts are being directed at the primary care level to reduce delay in the health care as well as strengthen primary health care services, it is also pertinent that tertiary health care facilities are adequately equipped to enable them deal with asphyxia-related organ injuries. Routine assessment of the serum cTnT in high-risk asphyxiated babies will enhance prompt detection of myocardial infarction in this population and has a great potential to improve management, reduce morbidity and mortality, and ultimately impact on the achievement of the United Nations Millennium Development Goal 4 which focuses on the reduction of childhood mortality. 17

Some advantages derivable from the point-of-care analysis of serum troponin levels adopted in the present study include the ease of procedure and short time interval required to obtain results. Future studies may also derive a correlation between selected physical signs and elevated cTnT in order to enhance clinical cardiovascular assessment in poor resource settings where the sophisticated equipment for measuring cTnT may not be affordable.
Finally, the current study is not without limitations. The relationships expressed between cTnT, umbilical arterial blood pH, and Apgar scores are correlations and not necessarily causations.

ack.title: Acknowledgment
ack.p: We acknowledge the advice and painstaking review of the written work by Charles Uzodimma; parents of the babies who gave us their consent; and the technical support from pediatric laboratory team, staff of obstetric, and neonatal intensive care units.

fn.label: Declaration of Conflicting Interests
fn.p: The author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The author(s) disclosed receipt of the following financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article: This work was funded by the authors. No fund was received from donors/commercial sources. Institutions of study provided structural and technical support. The authors have full control of the design of the study, methods used, outcome parameters, analysis of data, and production of the written report.

Presented at Cardiology 2011, 15th annual update on Paediatric and Congenital Cardiovascular Diseases: Bringing Interdisciplinary Evidence-Based Practice to the Patient, Arizona, USA; February 26, 2011. PASCAR conference, Munyoyo, Uganda; May 26–30, 2011.
